title: Should the trustee rent our my mother's home & charge my sister rent & can the rent from my two properties be used to pay bill?
question: My sister inherited two properties from my mother. One property is the home my mother lived in and the other property is where my sister has lived rent free for the last eighteen years. Two years ago my mother amended her trust and said the free rent was a “gift” to my sister for helping her out with personal care. My mother passed away last month and the trustee is not renting out my mother’s home nor is she asking my sister to pay any rent. I inherited two properties from my mother which have both been rented out for the last eighteen years. The trustee is telling me they can’t transfer title on the properties until the estate is settled because they need the rent from my two properties to pay bills. My mother also has over $500,000 in liquid assets that could be used to pay bills.
answers:
You really need an attorney. The answer to your question depends on the language in the trust. And, it involves a pretty technical, law-geek interpretation of the terms. The question depends on whether you are entitled to inherit the houses upon your mother's death or at the end of the trust administration period. It depends on how the trust allocates expenses. And, so on.

The trustee likely has a fair amount of discretion in the management of the trust. They might conceivably be allowed to use estate cash flow to pay ongoing bills. The issue is really about (1) how long they can reasonably administer the trust, and (2) whether they have to reimburse your share for any of the rents used to pay expenses.

I don't know how other attorneys handle this, but my firm offers a "protective engagement" where we represent a beneficiary in a non-hostile situation - just to make sure that the trustee plays by the book. Obviously, if they aren't following the rules, it can turn into a lawsuit. We try to keep it from coming to that point.

If "your" properties were given to you and are not assets of the trust then no, they cannot use your rental income to pay trust debts. If the properties are in trust, the general pot ($500,000 liquid assets) should be used to pay trust bills. The two houses given to your sister, she should pay the bills or rent the properties.

I really think that it would be very beneficial to you to have an attorney review the trust and hold the trust accountable - it sounds like the trustee may be favoring your sister and he/she cannot do that so it is good to get the situation back on track before it spirals out of control.

If the property were specifically given to you, they should not be used for paying any expenses if there are other assets. The income belongs to you from the date of death. As to your sister, if the properties were specifically given to your sister, she doesnt have to pay rent. That said, not renting your mother's house is a potential breach to your sister.

From the sound of things, you need an account from the trustee and need an explanation for using your income to pay general expenses. That said, your rent should be used to pay any expenses of your properties.

I think you need to retain an attorney.

The Trustee's obligation under most Trusts is to make distributions ASAP unless distributions are timed in the Trust document itself. Have the Trustee give you a copy of the Trust and go over it with an experienced Estate Planning attorney in Orange County. See Avvo.Com under Find-A-Lawyer. Good Luck!
